Carbon nanomaterials with sp2 or/and sp hybridization in energy
conversion and storage applications: A review
Yongzhi Wang,#a,b PengjuYang, #a,b Lingxia Zheng,a,b* Xiaowei Shia,b and Huajun Zhenga,b*
aState Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology,

sections.text:
E-mail: lxzheng@zjut.edu.cn (L. Zheng); zhenghj@zjut.edu.cn (H. Zheng) # These authors contribute equally to this work.
1
Abstract： Carbonaceous nanomaterials are widely considered in energy conversion and storage
applications owing to special structures and chemical-physical properties as well as
available versatile dimensionality. Huge interest has been paid recently in the
development of carbon allotropes with high degrees of sp hybridization as the
presence of ethynyl units can considerably affect their properties. In this review, the
general properties of three carbon allotropes with different hybridized carbon atoms
(graphene quantum dots (GQDs), graphdiyne and carbyne) are summarized. Special
focus has been given to the fabrication strategies and recent energy storage and
conversion applications based on GQDs and graphdiyne including supercapacitors,
lithium ion batteries and solar cells. Finally, conclusions and possible challenges are
proposed. This work will shed light on the fabrication of interesting carbon
nanomaterials for future energy-oriented applications.
Keywords. Graphene quantum dots, graphdiyne, supercapacitors, solar cells, ion
batteries, carbyne
2
1. Introduction.
Carbon is one of the most important elements in nature and is closely related to
the development of human history. Carbon nanomaterials demonstrate a variety of
properties such as the hardness—softness, insulator—semiconductor—conductor,
thermal insulation—thermal conductivity, full light absorption—full light
transmission, heat resistance, radiation resistance, chemical resistance, surface and
interface properties [1-7], etc, and they are extensively applied in a wide range of
fields including catalysis, electronics, energy storage, biomedicine and therapy [2, 8-17]. Thanks to the various combinations of carbon atom hybridization, such as sp3, sp2, sp, carbon allotropes with different structures and properties are obtained. Apart from two naturally existing carbon allotropes: diamond (sp3) and graphite (sp2), the discovery of fullerenes (sp2) [1], carbon nanotubes (sp2) [18, 19] and graphene (sp2)[20] expanded the categories of available versatile dimensionality of sp2-hybridized carbon materials (zero-, one-, and two-dimensional (0D, 1D, 2D),
respectively). Theoretically, carbon allotropes can be constructed by changing the periodic motifs within networks of sp3-, sp2-, and sp-hybridized carbon atoms due to
the versatile flexibility of carbon atoms [21-23]. Huge interest has been paid
nowadays in the development of carbon allotropes with high degrees of sp
hybridization because the presence of ethynyl units plays a significant role in the properties. In this regard, we aim at three allotropes with sp2 or/and sp hybridized
carbon atoms: graphene quantum dots (GQDs), graphdiyne (GDY) and carbyne. 0D GQDs material is taken as the representative for carbon allotropes with sp2
hybridization owing to a large surface area, low cytotoxicity, excellent solubility and
tunable bandgap, as well as quantum confinement effects and edge effects. The extended existence of sp2- and sp-carbon atoms endows 2D GDY material with high
π-conjunction, tunable electronic properties, and uniformly distributed pores, which
makes it a developing material star. The advent of so-called “carbyne” is an infinite
carbon chain with sp hybridization, and is regarded as the only true 1D carbon
allotrope. Special focus has been given to the fabrication strategies and recent energy
3
storage and conversion applications based on GQDs and GDYs including
supercapacitors, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) and solar cells.
As is well known that it has sensationalized the world and greatly promoted the
study of graphene-based materials when the research on graphene won the Nobel
Prize in Physics in 2010 [20]. Standing for a new type of quantum dots (QDs) with
unique properties associated with both graphene and QDs, GQDs are single or
few-layer graphene with a tiny size of only several nanometers. In contrast to the
other 0D carbon nanomaterials known as carbon dots that lack explicit structural
information, GQDs obviously possess graphene lattices inside the dots despite of the
dot size [24-26]. Comparing to its 2D native form, GQDs offer some unique merits
such as bandgap opening due to quantum confinement, excellent dispersibility, more
abundant active sites (edges, functional groups, dopants, etc.), better tunability in
chemicophysical properties, and comparable size to biomolecules [1, 27, 28]. Several
excellent reviews on GQDs have been published recently focusing on sensing [6, 25]
and bioimaging [29]. Regarding the energy-oriented applications, Wang et al. [27]
proposed a review on QDs derived from 2D materials including graphene, transition
metal dichalcogenide, graphitic carbon nitride, hexagonal boron nitride, and
phosphorene with an emphasis on catalysis and energy applications in 2016. Since
then, the energy field is rapidly evolving and many new exciting progresses have been
made. Therefore, latest significant developments on GQDs as the representative carbon allotrope with sp2 hybridization for energy storage and conversion applications
are needed.
As a new member of carbon nanomaterial family, graphyne (GY), which features
assembled layers of sp- and sp2-hybridized carbon atoms, has attracted tremendous
attention since the first serendipitous discovery in 1987 [30]. This planar, layered
material containing both acetylenic linkages and hexagonal rings was named for its
similar structure to graphite and ethyne (Figure 1a, b). It was not until 2010 that Li’s
group proposed a methodology to prepare large area graphdiyne (GDY) films on the
surface of copper via a cross-coupling reaction using hexaethynylbenzene (HEB) as precursor [31]. The excellent semiconductor feature (conductivity of 2.516 × 10−4 S
4
m−1) was similar to that of silicon, making GDY promising in electronics and semiconductors. This work verified the successful preparation of GDY with sp-sp2
carbon hybridization in the laboratory and promoted the rapid development of GDYs
in practical applications. Many efforts including theoretical calculations and
experimental results have been made during the last decade, exploring the potential
mechanical, optical and electronic properties of GDY based materials [15, 32-34].
In the 1960s, a suspected new carbon allotrope, called carbyne, was discovered
in a German crater called Chaoite, and triggered intensive interest all over the world.
The carbyne is an infinite carbon chain with sp hybridization, and the carbon–carbon
triple bond (sp) is a quite useful connecting unit owing to the structural linearity that
does not suffer from fluctuation originating from cis–trans isomerization. Theoretical
predictions reveal that carbyne is a very promising material with plenty of outstanding
5
properties. Unfortunately, it is difficult to synthesize and characterize carbyne, and
only linear carbon chains with dozens of carbon atoms in the laboratory were
successfully obtained at present. In this regard, only a brief overview of extraordinary
properties of carbyne is predicted regrading two possible geometric arrangements of
carbyne: cumulene with double bonds throughout the chain (=C=C=C=C=) and
polyyne with alternating single and triple bonds (-C≡C-C≡C-).
Herein, the general properties and fabrication methodologies of three carbon
allotropes (GQDs, GDYs and carbyne) are summarized. Special focus has been given
to the recent energy storage and conversion applications based on GQDs and GDYs
including supercapacitors, LIBs and solar cells (Figure 1c). The challenges and
perspectives are also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1 General properties
sections.text:
As a 2D crystal with mono-atomic layer, graphene is composed entirely of
carbon atoms and has a perfect hexagonal crystal structure. The arrangement of carbon atoms is bonded by sp2 hybrid orbitals in the same way as that of graphite
monoatomic layer. The unique 2D crystal structure of graphene offers many excellent properties [35], such as great specific surface area (2 630 m2 g-1), high electron mobility (200 000 cm2 (V·s)-1), high Young's modulus (≈ 1.0 TPa), high thermal conductivity (≈ 5 000 W (m·K)-1), high optical transmittance (≈ 97.7%) and excellent
conductivity [36-40]. One of the most important properties is its unique carrier
properties and mass-free Dirac Fermion properties [41]. The carriers in graphene
follow a special quantum tunneling effect and do not generate backscatter when they
encounter impurities, which is why graphene has superior conductivity and high
carrier mobility.
Interestingly, when the 2D graphene transforms to 0D (GQDs, i.e., lateral sizes
being reduced to typically <20 nm), superior or new properties emerge due to
prominent edge and quantum confinement effects, and meanwhile, some inherent
merits of the 2D parents are still preserved. GQDs are small graphene flakes usually
6
smaller than 100 nm in size and less than 10 layers in thickness, which bears defects
in graphitic lattice, chemical moieties and heteroatom dopants.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Photoluminescence properties
sections.text:
The photoluminescence (PL) properties of GQDs are intriguingly governed by
the combination or competition between intrinsic state and defect state emission [28].
The former derives from quantum confinement, edge effects (zigzag or armchair
edge), and radiative recombination of localized electron–hole pairs, while the latter is
induced by energy trap states because of chemical groups, dopants or vacancy defects
[27]. The high tunability makes it challenging to synthesize GQDs with homogeneous
properties, thus sometimes leading to contradictory hypotheses due to inconsistent
experimental observations. The fact that the PL properties of GQDs are determined by
numerous parameters results in unsettled PL mechanism for GQDs.
Compared to zero-bandgap semi-metallic 2D pristine graphene sheets, GQDs are
fluorescent and semi-conductive with size-dependent bandgaps due to quantum
confinement effect. Chen’s group systematically calculated the emission wavelength
of pristine zigzag-edged GQDs with different diameters ranging from 0.46 to 2.31 nm
(Figure 2a), and found that these GQDs (G1-G6) fluoresced from deep UV (bandgap
of 6.81 eV) to near infrared (bandgap of 1.64 eV) indicating the size dependent PL of
GQDs [42]. In addition to the prominent size-dependence, the excitation wavelength
dependence of the emission wavelength and intensity is another common
phenomenon observed in carbon-based fluorescent materials [28]. On the other hand,
heteroatom doping is another route to enhance fluorescence quantum yield [43] and
confer interesting up-conversion properties on GQDs originating from an anti-Stokes
transition or a multiphoton active process [44-46]. Li et al. [47] demonstrated that
nitrogen-doping (with pyridinic and pyrrolic N atoms; N/C atomic ratio of ca. 4.3%)
could cause the blueshift of GQD emission, to be specific, pyrrolic N-doping [42].
It was reported that small sp2 clusters isolated within the sp3 carbon network
were responsible for the PL emission of graphene oxide sheets [48-50]. Similarly, most synthesized GQDs were composed of isolated sp2 clusters, which dominated the
7
PL emission [42]. In general, GQDs mostly have some oxygen-containing functional
groups, such as hydroxyl, epoxy/ether, and carbonyl/carboxylic acid groups, leading
to the formation of “surface states”, which are the energy levels between π and π*
states of C=C. The resultant various energy levels may result in a series of emissive
traps. When a certain excitation wavelength illuminates the GQDs, a surface state
emissive trap will dominate the emission [51].
Figure 2. (a) Calculated emission wavelength as a function of the diameter of GQDs. The solid line is the linear fitting of zigzag-edged GQDs (G1–G6). Reproduced with permission [42]. Copyright 2014 The Royal Society of Chemistry. (b) High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images of GQDs for their major shapes and corresponding populations with increasing average size of GQDs. (c) Absorption spectra for three typical GQDs with average sizes of 12, 17, and 22 nm and graphene sheet. Inset: absorption peak energy as a function of average GQD size. Reproduced with permission [52]. Copyright 2012 American Chemical Society. (d-e) the effect of microwave heating time and source concentration on the absorbance of the GQDs, respectively. Reproduced with permission [51]. Copyright 2012 American Chemical Society.

sections.heading: 2.1.2 Absorption properties
sections.text:
GQDs usually possess wide rang absorption with a tail extending to visible
region. Two characteristic peaks are often observed in the UV-vis absorption spectrum:
one between 200–270 nm due to π–π* transition and the other between 270–390 nm
8
due to n–π* transition from C=O functional groups [26, 28]. The size dependent
optical absorption characteristics are attributed to the quantum confinement effect.
The absorption peak red-shifted from 270 nm to 330 nm when increasing the size
from 1–4 nm to 7–11 nm for GQDs synthesized by chemical oxidation and cutting of
carbon fibers at different temperatures [53]. While the hydrothermally prepared GQDs
also showed the same size dependence: with varying the average size of GQDs from 5
to 35 nm, the peak energy of the absorption spectra monotonously decreased (Figure
2b,c) [52]. However, for the GQDs prepared via glucose carbonization, the two
absorption peaks were independent of the size even though the size increased from
1.65 to 21 nm (Figure 2d,e) [51]. Besides, the variation of oxygen content was
reported to play important role in deciding the absorption peak position of GQDs [54].

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of GQDs
sections.text:
The preparation of GQDs is mainly divided into two categories: top-down and
bottom-up methods. The former usually employs various carbon materials (e.g.,
graphene sheets, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers) as precursors to be separated,
cut or peeled into small-sized GQDs by solvothermal, hydrothermal, mechanical,
chemical and electrochemical means, including acid oxidation, electron beam
irradiation, arc discharge, oxygen plasma treatment, microwave assisted irradiation,
etc. These methods are of low throughput, and produce GQDs with undesired lateral
size and thickness (layer number). The harsh conditions inevitably damage the
graphene lattice structure. While the bottom-up methods involve small organic
molecules as carbon precursors (e.g., glucose, hexa-peri-hexabenzocoronene, citric
acid) through dehydration, polymerization, and carbonization, such as fullerenes cage
opening methods, solution chemistry methods, pyrolysis of polycyclic aromatic
hydrocarbons, and unfocused laser irradiation, etc. The produced GQDs are always in
well-distributed sizes with controllable morphologies. However, tedious and
challenging synthetic procedures and poor yield are limitations.
9

sections.heading: 2.2.1.1 Electrochemical method
sections.text:
Electrochemical method is a common and intensively explored top-down
strategy for preparing GQDs owning to its low cost, easy post-treatment, simple
operation, high yield and good reproducibility, which could easily regulate the particle
size under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, the prepared GQDs exhibit good
stability without accumulation or color change when being stored in ambient
condition for a long period, such as 3 months [60]. While the disadvantage lies in the
long-time pretreatment of graphite raw materials, and the subsequently cumbersome
separation process. Generally, the mechanism of electrochemical reactions can be
explained by three main steps: i) Firstly, the electrolyte produces oxygen radicals (O·)
and hydroxyl radicals (HO·) which act on the anode, to oxidize and shear the crystal
lattice of graphite accompanying by the carboxyl plasma into the graphite layer. ii)
Then graphite anode expands significantly. Meanwhile, the outer edge region of
graphene undergoes oxidative decomposition reaction, and precipitation gradually
10
occurs in the solution. iii) At last, the graphite sheet is obviously peeled off from the
anode with most of the graphite fragmented into nanoscale GQDs [61-63].
Different electrode materials can be used in the electrochemical generation of
GQDs, such as graphite rod, carbon nanotube, carbon paste, carbon fiber and Pt sheets
with the carbon source in electrolyte solution [63-66]. Common electrolytes include
ionic liquid, acetonitrile containing tetrabutylammonium perchlorate and NaH2PO4 [67]. The electrode materials and electrolytes are important as they can render the
GQDs with different properties relating to surface states, cytotoxicity and PL
performance. For instance, Ananthanarayanan et al. [60] used an ionic liquid in
acetonitrile (10%, v/v)) as the electrolyte to offer high ionic conductivity and wide
electrochemical potential window, and produced high quality GQDs from monolithic
3D graphene grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) with good crystallinity,
uniform distribution of lateral diameter (~ 3 nm) and thickness (mostly single layer) at
a constant voltage of 5 V for 100 s (Figure 4a). Huang et al. [18] developed a weak
electrolyte-based (typically an ammonia solution) electrochemical method to enhance
the oxidation and cutting process (Figure 4b), and confirmed the significant
advantages of weak electrolyte for preparation GQDs. Compared with strong
electrolytes, the yield of GQDs (3~8 nm) obtained by this method was increased by
28 times.
11
Figure 4. (a) Schematic illustration of GQDs synthesis from 3D graphene. Reproduced with permission [60]. Copyright 2014 Wiley VCH. (b) Schematic diagram of the preparation of GQDs in strong and weak electrolyte solutions. Reproduced with permission [18]. Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society. (c) Mechanism for the hydrothermal cutting of oxidized graphene sheets into GQDs. Reproduced with permission [68]. Copyright 2010 Wiley VCH. (d) Synthesis procedure of GQDs. (e) Models of a portion of the hydrogel in water (left), and in an organic solvent (right). Reproduced with permission [69]. Copyright 2015 Elsevier. (f) Illustration of the oxidation and cage-opening of fullerene C60 with treatment of strong acid and chemical oxidant, and (g) Luminescence of GQDs excited with a blue laser pointer (405 nm). Reproduced with permission [59]. Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society.

sections.heading: 2.2.1.2 Hydrothermal method
sections.text:
Hydrothermal method is another common method for preparing GQDs with the
advantages of fast preparation speed and high quantum yield. However, it usually
requires a lot of reagents and time to obtain the raw materials first through a series of
chemical reactions. The mechanism was first proposed by Pan et al. [68] and is
schemed in Figure 4c: The graphene sheet is first treated with concentrated acid to
produce graphene oxide (GO), making the oxygen-containing functional group
attached to the edge and cavity of the graphene sheet forms linearly arranged epoxy chains. These epoxy chains surround the surrounding sp2 clusters, leading to the
12
breakage of C-C bonds in the region. Under hydrothermal conditions, the chemical
chains are easily open, and the oxygen atoms are detached, while the relatively stable
carboxyl groups are retained, resulting in excellent water-soluble GQDs.
Zhao et al. [55] used the commonly hydrothermal process to cut GO with
assistance of potassium superoxide (KO2) as proper “scissors”. The produced GQDs with yellow fluorescence in aqueous solution were obtained, and the yield was as high
as 35%. Qin et al.[69] developed a facile and ‘‘slow-release’’ method to prepare
GQDs by immersing graphene hydrogels in low-polarity organic solvents (Figure
4d,e). The obtained GQDs showed a strong fluorescence effect in the near ultraviolet
region with sizes of 2.3 nm to 3.8 nm. It was worth mentioning that this method
greatly simplified the post-treatment steps of the general hydrothermal method,
eliminating the need for filtration, centrifugation and dialysis.

sections.heading: 2.2.1.3 Solvothermal method
sections.text:
The solvothermal method utilizes organic solvents instead of water, and its
principle is very similar to that of hydrothermal method with advantages of strong
operability and controllability, as well as controllable size and shape of the products
by easily regulating the reaction conditions. Typically, in a closed reaction
environment, the substance is allowed to react in a liquid phase solvent under
conditions of high temperature and high pressure. Shin et al. [70] developed a novel
acid-free and solvothermal synthesis of GQDs using various natural carbon resources
including graphite, multiwall carbon nanotubes, carbon fibers, and charcoal. They
used oxone as a neutral oxidant to directly synthesize GQDs through one-pot
solvothermal method and followed by a simple purification step. The obtained GQDs
were fairly uniform with size distribution of 2-8 nm and exhibited a strong blue PL
under 365 nm UV light illumination. Note that it was the first time that GQDs had
been mass produced directly from natural carbon resources by solvothermal method.
Tian et al. [56] proposed a facile and environmentally friendly one-step solvothermal
method for the preparation of GQDs. In the N,N-dimethylformamide system,
hydrogen peroxide was used as the oxidant instead of concentrated sulfuric acid and
nitric acid and no impurities were introduced in the whole process. These GQDs had a
13
strong blue PL with a quantum efficiency of up to 15% and exhibited stable optical
properties at different pH values.
2.2.1.4 Others
GQDs can be obtained by other top-down methods such as microwave-assist
irradiation [71-73], ultrasonic-assisted cutting [74-77]. Shin et al. [78] reported a
one-pot synthesis of GQDs with high yield (70 ± 5 wt%) directly from graphite using
high-powered microwave irradiation, which can be used for mass production. Zhu et
al. [79] used graphene oxide as raw material to directly produce high-yield GQDs
under the assistance of ultrasound without adding any acid.

sections.heading: 2.2.2.1 Solution chemistry method
sections.text:
Solution chemistry is the most commonly used bottom-up method for preparing
GQDs. The size of GQDs prepared by this method can be precisely adjusted, and
usually has good water solubility. Generally, the water solubility and large size of
GQDs are not compatible by solution chemistry method. As the size of graphene
increases, the interaction between layers becomes stronger and the water solubility
drops greatly.
Yan et al.[57] obtained tunable and uniform GQDs by multiple 2′,4′,6′-triakyl
phenyl groups covalently attached to the edges of graphene moieties, which resulted
in reduced face-to-face interaction between the graphene sheets, thus effectively
increasing their solubility and producing stable GQDs larger than previously achieved.
The prepared GQDs contained 168, 132 and 170 carbon atoms, respectively, which
was the largest stable colloidal GQDs material reported at that time. The flexible side
chain was adsorbed onto the graphene, making the attraction between the solvent and
the side chain greater than that between graphene layers [80]. Subsequently, driven by
entropy, the spacing of the graphene layers become large, and then increasing water
solubility. However, for large-size GQDs, the interlayer force was greater than the
solubilizing power, which failed to achieve the above effect. Here, 2', 4', 6'-triakyl
14
phenyl was encapsulated on the outside of GQDs to form a 3D cage structure, so that
GQDs could no longer be stacked, which not only enhanced its water solubility but
also improved the stability.
Xu et al. [81] obtained GQDs solution with high solubility in organic solvents
with saturation of 5 mg mL-1~12 mg mL-1, which was much higher than traditional GQDs solution (0.01 mg mL-1~0.05 mg mL-1), and the average size reached 3.6 nm.
The specific procedure was to dissolve 2-naphthaldehyde in pure pyrrole under argon
atmosphere, then added a small amount of trifluoroacetic acid, and kept at 50 ℃ for
12 h. Subsequently, triethylamine, boron trifluoride and diethyl ether were separately
added and stirred, and the aqueous solution was extracted with dichloromethane after
washing with water. Then the aqueous solution was extracted with dichloromethane.
Finally, the organic layer was dried over magnesium sulfate. The GQDs can be
obtained by evaporation through filtration.

sections.heading: 2.2.2.2 Pyrolysis method
sections.text:
The pyrolysis method is heating small organic molecules above the melting point
to cause condensation, nucleation and then formation of large GQDs. The prepared
GQDs have high fluorescence yield, good dispersibility and stability, and can be
preserved for a long time. Meanwhile, the morphology and size of quantum dots can
be precisely controlled by regulating the pyrolysis temperature and precursor
molecules. Wu et al. [58] used the natural amino acid (L-glutamic acid) as a raw
material to prepare high-fluorescence GQDs by one-step pyrolysis. The fluorescence
quantum yield was as high as 54.5%, and showed strong blue, green and red
fluorescence under ultraviolet, blue and green illumination, respectively. Hong et al.
[82] synthesized ultrasmall single-layer GQDs (1.3±0.5 nm) by using trisodium citrate
as organic precursor. The obtained GQDs exhibited blue PL with the quantum yield of
3.6%, and the average fluorescence lifetime was 2.78 ns.

sections.heading: 2.2.2.3 Cage opening of fullerenes
sections.text:
Considering that each fullerene C60 molecule has the same shape and size, GQDs
of uniform size can be obtained upon the fragmentation of fullerene under specific
condition. When the surface of the fullerene adsorbs a catalytically active transition
15
metal layer, the fullerene layer can be catalytically decomposed to form a
graphite-like carbon layer. Lu et al. [83] first proposed the synthesis of geometrically
well-defined GQDs through ruthenium-catalyzed cage-opening of C60. Due to the interaction of C60 with Ru, vacancies were induced on the surface of Ru single crystal and the C60 molecule was embedded. After heating, the embedded C60 molecules were broken into carbon clusters, forming GQDs after diffusion and aggregation. More
importantly, the shape of the GQDs can be customized by controlling the annealing
temperature. Chua et al. [59] mixed an acid and other compounds as an oxidant to
induce oxidation, boiling and breaking of C60 (Figure 4f,g). The resulting GQDs remained completely dispersed in the aqueous suspension with lateral sizes within the
range 7-10 nm and a height of ~ 0.7 nm, and exhibited strong luminescent properties
with the highest intensity at 460 nm under a 340 nm excitation wavelength.
2.2.2.4 Others
Citric acid has been used as the carbon source to hydrothermally produce GQDs
[84]. The obtained GQDs exhibited uniformity in size (2-4 nm) and high
luminescence (quantum yield: >70%). Besides, microwave-assisted methods allow
the accelerated synthesis of GQDs under relatively mild conditions due to fast and
localized heating. Jeon et al. [85] reported the synthesis of doped GQDs using a
solvothermal reaction of norepinephrine precursor under microwave irradiation. The
synthesized GQDs exhibited lateral sizes of 3-4 nm and heights of 1-2 nm.

sections.heading: 2.3 Energy storage and conversion applications of GQDs
sections.text:
GQDs promise a wide range of energy storage and conversion applications due
to their large surface area, abundant active sites, tunable optical properties, good
biocompatibility, capability to facilitate charge transfer and transport and to intimately
integrate with other nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Supercapacitors, also named electrochemical capacitors, store energy based on
either electrochemical double layer effect or fast surface redox reactions
16
(pseudo-capacitance). The advantages lay on the fast charge/discharge rates
(compared with rechargeable batteries) and long cycle life (millions of cycles), as well
as a reasonable energy density (sometimes even close to batteries) [86, 87]. Presently,
commercial supercapacitors are mostly electric double-layer capacitors (EDLC),
because of their low cost and technical maturity. But the low energy density limits the practical application. In general, the energy density of EDLCs is less than 10 Wh kg-1, and this value is less than 50 Wh kg-1 for pseudocapacitors. Lots of work has been
done to effectively improve the energy density.
Compared with graphene sheets, GQDs have larger specific surface area, more
surface-active sites, and more accessible edges, which can conveniently afford full
accessibility of ion adsorption/desorption. Besides, the excellent electron mobility of
GQDs is favorable to increase the conductivity of the active layer and greatly
facilitates the charge transport through the active layer. By electrophoretic deposition
of GQDs on the interdigital Au finger microelectrodes, Liu et al. [88] constructed a
GQD-based symmetric micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) with high rate capability, high
frequency response, and outstanding cycle stability (97.8% retention after 5000
cycles). In addition, another kind of GQD-based asymmetric MSC involving
electrodeposited MnO2 nanoneedles was also assembled and two times higher specific capacitance (1107.4 µF·cm-2 at) and energy density (0.154 µWh·cm-2) were obtained
comparing to the symmetric MSC in the same aqueous solution. Huang et al. [89]
used GQDs to induce the morphological change of CuCo2S4 nanosheets from smooth surface to rough with particles accumulative features. Electrochemical performance
tests revealed that the GQD/CuCo2S4 electrode possessed a specific capacitance of 1725 F·g-1 at 0.5 A·g-1 and good cycling life (90% retention after 10000 cycles),
which was possibly due to the rich electroactive sites and short diffusion paths for
charge transport originated from the unique particles-accumulative morphology.
However, more work needs to be done to get insight into the formation mechanism of
the morphological evolution as no significant morphology change could be observed
when replacing CuCo2S4 by another bimetal oxide NiMoO4.
17
Besides, heteroatom doping (such as N [68, 90, 91], S [92-94], and B [95-97]) of
GQDs can effectively regulate their intrinsic properties including surface and local
chemical properties, optical and electrical properties. For instance, with close atomic
radius to carbon atoms, N atoms can change the electron donor/acceptor properties of
the graphene layer [90, 91], which affected the charge and discharge of the electric
double layer and the Faraday reaction of the tantalum capacitor, thereby effectively
improving the capacitance performance of GQDs-based electrodes. Li et al. [98]
synthesized N-doped GQDs (N-GQDs) by the alkali-catalyzed molecular fusion
method and assembled them onto the carbonized metal–organic framework (cMOF-5)
to produce hierarchical N-doped porous carbon electrode (Figure 5a-c). The obtained
N-GQDs offered a high concentration of active N and O sites owing to the most
marked edge effect and doping effect, which played an important role in enhancing
the pseudocapacitive activity and improving the surface wettability of the electrode,
while cMOF-5 provided an effective cubic porous framework with a large specific
surface area and good electrical conductivity. Therefore, the capacitance was boosted from 188 F·g-1 (cMOF-5) to 780 F·g-1 (N-GQD/cMOF-5) at a scan rate of 10 mV·s-1.
The N-GQD/cMOF-5 symmetric supercapacitor exhibited cyclic stability with 94.1%
retention after 5000 cycles and 84.6% retention after 12 000 cycle with coulombic
efficiency of 92.2%, confirming the good cycling life and excellent stability.
Moreover, when used as the positive electrode, the N-GQD/cMOF-5//AC (activated carbon) asymmetric supercapacitor exhibited an energy density of 14.4 Wh·kg-1 at a power density of 400.6 W·kg-1 (under a wide potential window of 0~1.6 V). The
lightening behavior also indicated the high energy density (inset of Figure 5c).
Zheng et al. [99] used an electrochemical method to synthesize
amino-functionalized GQDs (af-GQDs) and designed Ni(OH)2/af-GQDs composites (Figure 5d-f). The layered Ni(OH)2 nanosheets were spaced by -NH2 groups from af-GQDs in a self-assembled manner, forming a sandwiched structure with a large
pore size of 1.8 nm, which reduced the accumulation of Ni(OH)2 nanosheets and increased electrode surface area. The introduction of af-GQDs led to enhanced
electrical conductivity, the accessibility of the charged ions and better cycling stability
18
as well as contributing additional EDLC. So the specific capacitance reached 2653 F·g-1 at 1 A g-1 in 1 M KOH solution with good rate capability. As for the asymmetric
supercapacitor based on Ni(OH)2/af-GQDs and electrochemical-exfoliated graphene , it exhibited a wide potential window range (~1.8 V), a high energy density, and an
excellent cycling stability with 90.15% capacitance retention.
2.3.2 Lithium ion batteries
19
With the continuous development of high-tech products such as portable devices
and electric vehicles, people's requirements for the performance of LIBs batteries
keep rising [17, 19, 100-102]. As a traditional electrode material, graphite has the
advantages of low cost and high chemical stability. Moreover, graphite is one of the
earliest commercial anode materials for LIBs [103]. But it has low lithium ion
diffusion coefficient, and the low theoretical maximum capacity of graphite (372 mAh g-1, LiC6) hardly meets our demand for high-capacity batteries [104, 105]. In this regard, GQDs are expected to show great potential due to the tunable size and surface
chemistry. The introduction of GQDs not only affects the electrolyte transport, but
also greatly improves the electron transfer and the lithium storage capacity [106].
Chao et al. [107] designed a novel type of binder-free cathode by bottom-up
growth of biface VO2 arrays directly on graphene foam and then coating uniformly with GQDs by electrophoresis deposition (GVG electrode) (Figure 6a,b). Here, the
GQDs acted as sensitizer to improve ion diffusion and charge transport kinetics;
meanwhile, the homogeneous GQDs coverage can suppress the dissolution of VO2 and agglomeration of the arrays. Thus, the GVG electrode delivered a capacity more than 420 mAh·g-1 and capacity retention of 94% after 1500 cycles at 18 A·g-1 in lithiation. During sodiation, it can also exhibit a high capacity of 306 mAh·g-1 and
superior rate tolerance, as well as good capacity retention (88% after 1500 cycles at 18 A·g-1) with a power density of 42 kW·kg-1 at an energy density more than 100 Wh·kg-1. Guo et al. [108] synthesized GQDs doped MoS2 nanosheets via a facile solvothermal method with boosted electrochemical lithium storage properties. The
doped GQDs served as conducting components to enhance the electron transfer in the
poorly conductive MoS2, and also as toughening additives to buffer the volume variation and thus improving the cyclic stability of the electrode. As expected,
compared with the pristine MoS2, the obtained GQDs/MoS2 electrode exhibited high reversible capacity (1099 mA h·g-1 at 100 mA·g-1), good cyclic stability and excellent rate performance (660 mAh·g-1 at 5000 mA·g-1).
20
Figure 6. (a) Scheme of the GVG electrode with bicontinuous electron and Li/Na ion transfer channels. (b) Ragone plot based on the total mass of the whole electrode, the sloping lines indicate the relative time to get the charge in or out of the electrodes. Reproduced with permission [107]. Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society. (c) Preparation routine and structure of yolk–shell NiO/GQD microspheres. (d) Cycling performances of NiO/GQDs-COOH and NiO/GQDs-NH2 at 0.1 A g−1. Reproduced with permission [109]. Copyright 2018 Wiley-VCH.
Similarly, Yin et al. [109] selected carboxyl-functionalized GQDs and af-GQDs
to modify yolk–shell NiO microspheres to give NiO/GQDs electrodes (Figure 6c,d).
The modification of GQDs on the surface also served both as a conductive media for
better electron transfer and as an addictive buffer to alleviate the volume change
during cycling. Compared with the capacitance of bald NiO without GQDs modification (396 mAh·g-1), the obtained NiO/GQDs-COOH and NiO/GQDs-NH2 electrodes displayed remarkably improved lithium storage performance with a specific capacity of 1081 and 834 mAh·g-1 after 250 cycles at 0.1 A·g-1, respectively.
The slightly better behavior of NiO/GQDs-COOH that that of NiO/GQDs-NH2 was
21
possibly due to a higher content of functionalized GQDs with more uniformly
distribution on surfaces of NiO microspheres and stronger electronegativity of oxygen
atoms in carboxyl groups than that of nitrogen atoms in amino groups in the GQDs.

sections.heading: 2.3.3 Solar cells
sections.text:
Solar cells are one of the most promising new energy conversion devices, and
their emergence has brought a new dawn to solve the problem of global resource
shortage. The possible wide-range absorption of GQDs makes them attractive for
designing efficient solar cells. Besides, the two orders of magnitude slower hot carrier
cooling rate (100–300 ps) of GQDs (compared with bulk graphene) also enables more
efficient hot charge carrier harvesting in solar energy conversion [110]. Travis G.
Novak et al. [111] proposed that the functionalization of GQDs with low molecular
weights of polyethylene glycol (PEG) significantly improved the GQD interaction
with the P3HT:PCBM (poly 3-hexylthiophene: 6,6-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl
ester) active layer, resulting in improved power conversion efficiency (PCE) of
organic solar cells. The reason was possibly because that faster P3HT exciton
dissociation in GQD containing cells led to an absorption improvement in the visible
range due to fewer bound charges remaining in P3HT (Figure 7a,b). Jaehoon Ryu et
al. [112] found that the introduction of the GQDs into planar-type perovskite solar
cells boosted the short-circuit current density (Jsc), open-circuit voltage (Voc) and fill factor (FF) by the ultrafast electron extraction to the blocking TiO2 layer (Figure 7c,d). Size effect of GQDs on cell performance was studied and the results revealed
that the devices with appropriately sized-GQDs showed an average PCE of 10%
enhancement compared with those cells without GQDs (19.11% as the best PCE).
22
Figure 7. (a) J–V curves of devices with various types of GQDs and comparison to the reference cells. Inset shows the basic device design. (b) UV–vis on P3HT:PCBM thin films with normalized absorption peaks showing a redshift with functionalization decreasing chain length. Reproduced with permission [111]. Copyright 2016 wiley-VCH. (c) The energy diagram of GQD-applied planar perovskite solar cells, and (d) time-resolved photoluminescence spectra of perovskite on the TiO2 layer and perovskite on GQD modified-TiO2 films, excited at 405 nm; the instrument response function (IRF) is measured to confirm time resolution of the system. Reproduced with permission [112]. Copyright 2017 Royal Society of Chemistry.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Molecular structure
sections.text:
Graphynes (GYs) are generally composed of benzene rings and acetylenic
linkers. By accounting for the number of acetylene bonds between two benzene rings,
GYs can be distinguished as graphyne, graphdiyne, graphtriyne and so on (Figure 8a).
By varying the linkages of acetylene bonds, GYs can also be split into different planar
structures, such as 6,6,12-, α-, and β-GY, which have also been theoretically discussed
and reviewed [95, 113, 114]. Four different types of C–C bonds can be found in GYs. (1) C(sp2)–C(sp2) bonds of the benzene rings with bond lengths of ~1.426 Å; (2) C(sp2)–C(sp) bonds between neighboring C═C double bonds and C≡C triple bonds,
23
bond lengths of 1.407Å; (3) C(sp)–C(sp) triple carbon bonds, bond lengths of 1.223 Å;
(4) single C–C bonds linking two adjacent C≡C bonds [115]. The GY monolayer has
the same hexagonal symmetry (P6m) as graphene.
Figure 8. (a) Structure of GYs. Reproduced with permission [95]. Copyright 2012 American Physical Society. (b) Band structures and density of states (DOS) of GDY at the LDA and GW levels. Optical transitions between the first two Van Hove singularities are indicated. Reproduced with permission [116]. Copyright 2011 American Physical Society.
Note that only graphdiynes (GDYs) can be prepared in the laboratory, and most
reported studies focus on GDYs. Thus, we will mainly discuss GDYs in this review.
GDY is a large triangular ring of 18-carbon atoms with the introduction of butadiyne
linkages (−C≡C−C≡C−) [117, 118], demonstrating a 2D flat porous network, making
it the most stable non-natural carbon allotrope containing diacetylene bonds [119]. In
GDY, the bond lengths are1.33 Å for the single C–C bonds linking two adjacent C≡C
bonds, which has some character of double bonds for the effect of multiple conjugation [120]. Due to the sp and sp2 carbon atoms and their related bonds, GDYs
display greater structural flexibility than graphene, which offer the opportunity to
form curved structures. In an infinite plane, GDY has a 2D planar structure similar to
graphene, which can be simply regarded as about one-third of the C-C bonds in
graphene inserted into two C≡C bonds [121]. The 2D planar structure is formed via
van der Waals force and π-π interaction, which endows a high degree of π-conjugation
character, evenly dispersed pores, and tunable electronic structure [122].

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Electronic structure
sections.text:
In contrast to zero band gap of graphene, GY allotrope has a natural band gap, and
24
can be directly applied to photoelectric devices [123, 124]. As shown in Figure 8b,
the band gap is 0.44 eV at the local density approximation (LDA) level and increases
to 1.10 eV at the GW level [116]. The 1.5 times quasiparticle correction is due to the
enhanced Coulomb interaction in reduced dimensionality. Interestingly, the energy
band gap values of GDY can be widely tuned by hydrogenation or halogenation [125],
making them promising candidates in optoelectronic devices. Due to the special role
of C≡C bonds, GYs has versatile Dirac cones as suggested by the density functional
theory (DFT) calculation results [95]. The C≡C bonds modulate effective hopping
matrix elements and reverse their signs, resulting in Dirac cones of GYs having the
characteristics of reversed chirality, momentum shift and switch of the energy gap
[96]. GYs is a self-doped semiconductor that already has charge carriers, unlike
graphene that requires additional doping [126]. The intrinsic hole and electron mobility of 6,6,12-GYs can reach 4.29×105 and 5.41×105 cm2 (V s)-1, respectively [123, 127], larger than those of graphene. The flat sp– and sp2– hybridized carbon
network endows GDY with unique electronic structure, electrical conductivity, and
high chemical stability [128, 129].

sections.heading: 3.2 Preparation of GDYs
sections.text:
Since the first successful synthesis of GDY in 2010 [31], researchers all over the
world have been trying to explore different synthetic methods and some progress has
been made. The current synthetic methods of GDY include template coupling method
in organic solvent [10, 130-132], chemical vapor deposition method [133, 134],
two-phase coupling method [8, 135] and explosive coupling method [136, 137].
Among them, the template coupling method in organic solvent is the most common
and mature strategy. Zhou et al. [138] synthesized the GDY nanowalls (GDY-NWs)
by using the modified Glaser-Hay coupling reaction (Figure 9a). In this process, Cu
ions acted as catalysts, where the Glaser coupling reaction of HEB monomers
occurred; pyridine acted as both ligand and solvent to dissolve Cu ions from the
surface of Cu foil. Figure 9b revealed both the high crystallinity of GDY-NWs in
certain areas (0.466 nm, top) and curved GDY sheets (0.365 nm, bottom). Results
25
showed that the GDY-NWs with regular structure were tolerant to a high current
attributed to the conjugated structure and showed extraordinary and stable
field-emission properties, indicating GDY as an excellent candidate for all-carbon
electric devices. Shang et al. [131] used the Glasser-Hay method with HEB as the
precursor to successfully grow GDY nanosheets with an average thickness of ca. 1.9
nm on Cu nanowire-based paper substrate at room temperature (Figure 9d-e). Herein,
the Cu nanowire paper not only served as a catalyst for the in-situ growth of GDYs,
but also as a substrate to provide more reaction sites for the growth of GDYs.
Figure 9. (a) Scheme of the experimental setup. (b,c) HRTEM images of GDY nanowalls; related SAED (selected area electron diffraction) patterns are in corresponding insets. Reprodcued with persimmison [138]. Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society. (d) Representation of the synthesis, (e) SEM image and (f) HRTEM image of GDY nanosheets on Cu nanowire paper. Reproduced with permission [131]. Copyright 2018 Wiley-VCH.

sections.heading: 3.3 Energy storage and conversion applications of GDYs
3.3.1 Supercapacitors
sections.text:
GDY is a new type of material with good conductivity and large porosity, which
is suitable for rapid charging and discharging processes in supercapacitors [139, 140].
The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Figure 10a) of the GDY electrode had a quasi-rectangular shape at different scan rates from 5 to 100 mV s-1, indicating both
the EDLC and the Faraday reactions based charge storage mechanisms [141]. The specific capacitance reached 71.4 F g-1 at 3.5 A g-1. The GDY electrode also exhibited good cycling stability with 97% retention after 1000 cycles at 50 mV s-1 (Figure 10b).
26
Moreover, Xu et al. [142] demonstrated that GDYs can be used as a promising
substrate for growing MnO2 nanospheres, owing to their large surface area and highly conjugated electronic structure for the first time. The oxidation form (graphdiyne
oxides, GDYO) was proved to be an even excellent substrate for MnO2 growth to enhance the capacitor performance. The MnO2@GDYO electrode had a high specific capacitance of 301 F g-1 at 0.2 A g-1 and 98% initial capacitance retention was
observed after 3000 cycles.
Figure 10. (a) CV curves at different scan rates; (b) capacitance retention over 1000 cycles measured using CV method and the inset shows the Nyquist plot of GDY electrodes before and after cyclic tests. Reprocued with permission [141]. Copyright 2016 Elsevier. (c) Schematic illustration of preparation processes; (d) the N and O content in the as-prepared GDYs and (e) long-term retention at a charge/discharge current density of 5A g-1. Reprocued with permission [136]. Copyright 2018 Elsevier.
In order to further improve the performance of graphene-based supercapacitors,
the state-of-the-art heteroatom-doping approaches are implemented in tuning the
characters for further imrovement in electrochemical devices. The chanllenge lies in
the controlling of heteroatom content and doping configurations and it is difficult to
break through the controversy in recognizing the active role of heteroatoms. Shang et
al. [136] proposed the good editability of GDYs by a novel method for tailoring their
N-doping configuration, N-content, and micropores (Figure 10c-e). Via a solvent- and
metal-catalyst-free method in air at 120 °C, single N and triazine-like N cluster were
27
successfully introduced into GDYs. Results revealed that N addition increased the
band gap of GDY and produced more structural defects. The specific capacitance of
N0-GDY maintained 95.6% of the initial specific capacitance when cycling 3000 times at 5A g-1, proving good electrochemical stability. However, the N-doping
method dramatically affected the capacitive behavior. It was found that the pyridinic
N-doping strategy retarded the GDYs response to fast charge/discharge behavior,
leading to 50% drops of the manximum capacitance, which might be attributed to the
depressed electronic delocalization via N-doping.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Lithium ion batteries
sections.text:
The unique characteristics of GDY, such as asymmetrically distributed
π-electrons [143, 144], semiconducting property, and porous 2D structure [143, 145],
large specific surface area, and high conductivity, might provide a new option for the
lithium storage applications [146-148]. Compared to graphite-based electrode
materials, the specific capacities and lithiation potentials of GDY are greatly
enhanced [148, 149]. By DFT calculations, it was found the theoretical capacity was twice the value of graphene (744 mAh g-1, LiC3) by adsorbing lithium on the surface because of the presence of acetylene bonds of GDY [150]. The lithiation potentials of
GDY range from 2.7 to 2.1 V. Meanwhile, due to the large triangular pores of GDY,
lithium ions can pass through the layers to form an out-of-plan diffusion with the
diffusion energy of only 0.18-0.48 eV [151]. Lou et al. [152] and Zhang et al. [153]
studied the energy and kinetics process of lithium in single-layer GDY by
first-principle theory and found that the diffusion direction of lithium is not only
parallel to the interlayer plane of the GDY layer, but also between the triangular pores,
which makes graphite alkyne suitable for the anode material of LIBs [154].
Huang et al. [155] prepared GDY-based electrode on the surface of Cu without
binder, which exhibited superior electrochemical performance including high specific
capacities, outstanding rate performance, and long cycle life (Figure 11a,b). The obtained reversible capacities were up to 520 mAh g-1 after 400 cycles at 500 mA g-1; and 420 mAh g-1 after 1000 cycles at 2 A g-1. The authors elucidated the method
28
behind the Li atom storage in multilayer GDY by using GDY with varying thickness.
The intercalation of Li atoms occurred primarily through both interlayer
insertion/extraction process and surface absorption/desorption process. However, the
performance is still far from the theoretical capacity value of GDY electrode.
Therefore, more work needs to be done to further enhance the lithium storage
performance of GDY. For instance, it is necessary and effective to improve the graded
pores between the GDY monolayer film and sheet layer, as well as increasing the
active sites to promote the ion diffusion rate. Wang et al. [156] designed a new type of
anode based on self-assembled GDY-nanowalls with a unique hierarchical porous
structure (Figure 11c). The electrochemical results showed that GDY-nanowalls electrode demonstrated a reversible capacity of 908 mAh g-1 at 0.05 A g-1 and maintained a reversible capacity of 526 mAh g-1 after 10,000 cycles at 1 A g-1.
Recently, Shang et al. [146] proposed an in-situ method to construct 3D GDY network
under extremely low temperature condition (25℃) (Figure 11d,e). The GDY
nanosheet was grown in situ by the mechanism of Glaser cross-coupling reaction.
They claimed that the reasonable voids with the flexible GDY walls were helpful for
solving the problems of interface contact and volume change of silicon anode during
the cycle process, leading to excellent cycle stability, high capacity and good rate performance. The capacity reached 4122 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 with robust capacity retention (1503 mA h g−1) after 1450 cycles at 2 A g−1.
29
Figure 11. (a) Scheme of the GDY synthesis and LIBs preparation process. (I) synthesis schematic of GDY. (II) photograph of GDY sample and Ball-and-stick model of the structure of GDY. (III) representation of an assembled GDY-based battery. (b) Cycle performance of the GDY-based electrodes at a current density of 500 mA g-1. Reproduced with permission [155]. Copyright 2014 Elsevier. (c) Scheme of synthesis of GDY-nanowalls and their assembly into LIBs. Reproduced with permission [156]. Copyright 2017 Elsevier. (d) SEM image of the FPCuSi after weaving GDY. (e) Possible mechanism for achieving the high performance in the GDY-modified Si anode. Reproduced with permission [146]. Copyright 2018, Wiley-VCH.
Recently, doped heteroatoms (such as N and O) in 2D materials have been found
to be active sites for lithium storage because of their electronegative properties,
beneficial for further improvement of the electrochemical performance of the carbon
network. As a well-established way, nitrogen (N) doping could generate heteroatomic
defects to increase electrochemical active binding sites, achieving enhanced
electrochemical performance [157-162]. Similar to the case in supercapacitors, the big
30
challenge lies in how to control the content and type of N atoms. Yang et al. [163]
reported the qualitative and quantitative N doping strategy for carbon materials by
preparing self-supporting, uniform and continuous pyrimidine-GDY (PM-GDY) and
pyridine-GDY (PY-GDY) films (Figure 12a,b). On account of their large area and
porosity, this carbon material can be directly applied as the anode in LIB. As expected,
PM-GDY and PY-GDY exhibited excellent electrochemical performance: PY-GDY showed a reversible capacity of 1168 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1, and PM-GDY maintained 483 mAh g-1 at 5000 mA g-1 after 4000 cycles.
31
up a LED lamp (right). (b) The optimized AA stacked configurations with corresponding interlayer spacing of bilayer PY-GDY and PM-GDY from top and side view. Reproduced with permission [163]. 2018 American Chemical Society. (c) Typical motif design. (d) N2 adsorption– desorption isotherm curves showing the well-developed porosity and specific surface area of 422 m2 g-1. (e) The cycle performance at 50 mA g-1. All the potentials are vs. Li+/Li. Reproduced with permission [164]. 2018 Royal Society of Chemistry.
Compared to N-doped GDY, fluorine atoms doping exhibits similar
characteristics in lithium storage and is more stable in electrolytes during redox
reactions. He et al. [164] used a solution-based method to synthesize 2D
fluoride-doped graphdiyne (F-GDY) by C-C coupling reaction, which could be
simply viewed as fluorine substituted GDY (Figure 12c-e). The uniform distribution
of F atoms in the 2D plane made the lithium ions being inserted into F-GDY more
stable, resulting in more active sites. Meanwhile, the macroporous structure in the 2D
molecule improved the diffusion of lithium ions in the vertical direction. The flexible
half-cell assembled with F-GDY as the cathode showed a reversible capacity of 1700 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1, and remained a reversible capacity of approximately 350 mAh g-1 after 9000 cycles at 2 A g-1, therefore, it is predictable that F-GDY is a good option
for the next generation of flexible electrode materials in LIBs.

sections.heading: 3.3.3.1 Perovskite solar cells
sections.text:
Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have huge commercial attraction due to their high
efficiency and easy solution process using cheap materials. MAPbI3-based PSCs have achieved great success in recent years, and their power conversion efficiency (PCE)
has exceeded 20% [97, 165-170], owing to the low exciton binding energy of the
perovskite material and the tunable visible light absorption band [171]. The properties
of electron transport layers (ETLs) play a crucial role in determining the performance
of PSCs [62, 172-176]. Jiu et al. [177] firstly demonstrated that GDY doped in both
PCBM film and ZnO thin film PSC based on MAPbI3 with an inverted structure (Figure 13a-c). The results showed that GDY doping increased the conductivity,
electron mobility and charge extraction ability in the ETL. This way led to the PCE
32
increased from 16.6% to 20.0% based on MAPbI3 active layer. Moreover, the devices based on dual doped GDY exhibited a remarkable improved stability and J-V
hysteresis. Li et al.[178] developed a simple method to use GDY as the host material
for the active layer of perovskite and found that the introduction of GDY can improve
the morphology of the active layer, and achieved a uniform MAPbI3 film with high crystallinity, large domain sizes, and few grain boundaries (Figure 13d-f). The XPS
results revealed the possible reasons for the crystallinity enhancement. The binding
energies of Pb 4f peak and I 3d peak in PbI2 (GDY) were both reduced by about 0.2 eV compared to those for PbI2, which may be induced by the Pb atom binding to the GDY coordinate bond to absorb more electrons, as well as inhibiting iodide ion
vacancy formation, and thereby improving the crystal quality and the stability of the
MAPbI3 film. The optimal PCE of the MAPbI3 (GDY)-based device reached 21.01% (PCE without GDY was 16.69%), and other parameters such as fill factor (FF) and
short-circuit current (Jsc) were also significantly improved. Another effective method to boost the electronic transmission property is adding dopants into the electron
transportation layer (ETL) of PSC (e.g., N-doping).[179]
33
and a relative humidity (RH) of 60%, the PCE of PVSK/GDY device was nearly
unchanged and still maintained 95% after 140 days.

sections.heading: 3.3.3.2 Dye sensitized solar cells
sections.text:
Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have the virtues of low production cost, high
energy conversion efficiency, and simple manufacturing, which have been regarded as
an alternative to silicon-based solar cells [173, 181, 182]. Nevertheless, their
applications have been limited by the reservation of precious metal Pt which has
traditionally been the material choice for the counter electrode on account of its
resistance to electrolyte corrosion, high conductivity, and excellent catalytic
34
performance for iodine reduction. A typical DSSC device usually contains a
dye-sensitized anode, electrolyte, and a counter electrode. The counter electrode plays an important role in a DSSC device, which is to catalyze the triiodide/iodide (I3 −/I−) redox couple of the electrolyte. Many efforts have been devoted to reducing or
replacing Pt-based electrodes in DSSCs [72, 82, 183-187]. One promising approach is
by taking advantage of carbon materials as the counter electrodes [188-191].
Due to its unique structure, GDY shows n-type semiconductor behavior with
moderate bandgap. Its electron cloud density is reported to be higher than that of
graphene based on theoretical calculation results [193]. It could be more easily to
form chemical bonds between GDY and Pt nanoparticles (PtNPs) owing to the 3d
unoccupied orbitals in Pt, beneficial for enhancing electron transfer and catalytic
performance [90]. As expected, Hao et al. [192] demonstrated the successful
preparation of PtNPs onto GDY nanosheets by ion-beam sputtering, which endowed a
special "p-n" structure (Figure 14a-b). The DFT calculations showed that this
35
structure improved the catalytic performance and electron transfer when used as
counter electrode in DSSCs. The experimental results confirmed that the performance
of PtNPs-GDY nanosheets was almost equivalent to that of metal Pt foil, and was
even superior to that of reduced graphene oxide/PtNPs composite and PtNPs. Zhu et
al. [194] successfully prepared GDY-doped TiO2 (P25)-based photoanodes with superior cell performance. The optimal photoanode achieved the best PCE of 8.03%,
which was increased by 26.5% comparing with that of undoped cell. The reason was
because the introduction of GDY increased the dye adsorption capability, accelerated
the electron transfer rate and reduced the charge recombination.

sections.heading: 3.3.3.3 Colloidal quantum dot solar cells
sections.text:
Colloidal quantum dot solar cell (CQDSC) is expected to be a leader in the next
generation of photovoltaic devices because of its low cost, good stability, quantum
size effect and adjustable bandgap [195-202]. It is a feasible path to improve the
performance of CQDSC by introducing a buffer layer between the CQD active layer
and the anode. Jin et al. [203] spin-coated GDY on PbS-EDT (EDT: 1,2-ethanedithiol)
as an anode buffer layer to greatly improved the performance of photovoltaic devices
(Figure 15). Compared with the reference device without GDY, the PCE increased
from 9.49% to 10.64%. In addition, the Impedance spectroscopy (IS) results indicated
that the effective carrier lifetimes were determined to be 2.4 and 1.9 µs under
illumination for devices with and without GD, respectivley, (corresponding values in
the dark were 22.8 and 20.2 µs, respectively). The longer carrier lifetime of the device
indicated that photogenerated carriers needed more time to move toward, and
ultimately be collected by the Au anode, in consistent with the larger recombination
resistance of the device (the diameter of the semicircle), which indicated less carrier
recombination inside the device. The longer carrier lifetime and larger recombination
resistance should be induced by the improved contact between the PbS-EDT layer and
the Au anode. Forturnately [123, 127], GDY material can be used as an ideal electron
transport layer and hole transport material owing to the intrinsic hole and electron
mobilities [143], [148]. It can be used as both dopant to enhance the electron transport
36
rate of ETL, and directly as the subject of hole transfer to improve the device
performance. Therefore, it has promising and encouraging potential in optoelectronic
devices, especially solar cells in the future.
Figure 15. (a) Schematic illustration of the PbS CQDSC with GDY anode buffer layer; (b) J–V characteristics under simulated AM 1.5 G irradiation; IS (impedance spectroscopy) results of the devices under a bias of 0.3 V: (c) In dark and (d) under simulated AM 1.5 illumination. Reproduced with permission [203]. Copyright 2016 Wiley-VCH.

sections.heading: 4. Carbyne—Linear carbon chains
sections.text:
Since the proposal of “The era of carbon allotropes” by A. Hirsch in 2010 [204],
the case of “lacking allotrope” consisting of sp-hybridized carbon atoms called
carbyne showed a huge interest in the past [205]. The fact that sp-carbon atoms are very easily to react and crosslink to form sp2- or sp3- carbon atoms makes it a big
challenge to obtain very long carbon chains. A lot of controversy about whether the
carbyne was existed arose until the fabrication of the stable systems of polyynes: short
sp hybridized linear carbon arrangements with end-capping groups [206]. DFT
calculations on model chains revealed that the transition from finite length chains
ruled by end-effects to a chain ruled by Peierls distortion (that was following the
behavior of an ideally infinite 1D system) occurred for chains having more than 50
carbon atoms [207]. In real systems, finite length effects and end-groups play a
37
fundamental role and drive the system to a specific degree of bond length alternation:
the terminal groups affect the overall wire configuration with an increasingly larger
effect in shorter wires. Due to the difficulty in synthesis and characterization, we still
know very little about carbyne.
The ideal carbyne generally has two structures, as shown in Figure 16a [13].
One is called cumulene with double bonds throughout the chain (=C=C=C=C=) and
the other is polyyne with alternating single and triple bonds (-C≡C-C≡C-). The
38
polyyne, respectively. Reproduced with permission [13]. Copyright 2016 Royal Society of Chemistry. (b) Experimental and simulated images of straight carbyne and alkane. a. Averaged TEM image of straight carbyne. The red-framed area in a) was modeled and simulated as shown in c-h. c-e Modeled, simulated, and filtered images of straight carbyne C11, terminated by Pt atoms. f-h Modeled, simulated, and filtered images of zigzag alkane C11H22, terminated by Pt atoms. Simulated images of d and g were obtained at 4 nm defocus. Reproduced with permission [208]. Copyright 2014 Elsevier.
Various chemical and physical strategies mainly in a bottom-up manner have
been employed to produce linear carbon chains of possibly different lengths [13, 14,
209, 210], whilst spectroscopic measurements were performed to characterize the
structural, vibrational and electronic properties [211]. Techniques based on physical
vapour deposition methods depend on the rapid quenching of carbon vapour/plasma
produced by arc discharge/laser ablation to induce carbon clusters under
out-of-equilibrium conditions [212-215]. While two chemical approaches are often
explored to synthesize a large number of sp carbon chains terminated with different
molecular groups. One is the polymerization strategy [216] and the other targets
molecules with a defined length and specific endgroups [217-219]. On the other hand,
the top-down methods are based on pulling a carbon nanotube or graphene in order to
form a wire as predicted by theoretical studies. For example, polyynes can be formed
using Pt atoms on graphene [208] and the formation of Pt-endcapped 1D wires has
been observed by TEM images (Figure 16b) where Pt atoms acted as nucleation sites
of additional carbon atoms. Nevertheless, the structure stability is still a key issue as
explosions are possible upon isolation of sp-carbon wires in the solid state, especially
in the case of H-terminated polyynes [205].
Theoretical predictions indicate that carbyne is a very promising material. A brief
overview of some outstanding properties is predicted as follows. First, the effective surface of carbyne is estimated to exceed 13 000 m2 g-1 [220], which is four times
higher than the theoretical value of graphene. Benefitted from the strong σ-bonds,
carbyne probably endows the best mechanical strength, a very high value of Young’s modulus (up to 32 TPa) and a specific stiffness of about 109 N m kg-1 [2]. These
values are much higher than those of other carbon materials, such as carbon nanotubes,
39
graphene and even diamonds. In addition, the thermal conductivity of carbyne is excellent, what is estimated to exceed 20 080 kW m-1 K-1 for cumulenes and polyynes at room temperature. Compared with graphene (5 kW m-1 K-1) and carbon nanotubes (3.5 kW m-1 K-1) which exhibit the best thermal conductivity known at present; the
gap is quite obvious. Such superhigh thermal conductivity is attributed to high phonon
frequencies and long phonon mean free path allowing ballistic thermal transport up to
the micron-scale [221]. As for electronic properties, as mentioned above, cumulene is
expected to be a metal while polyyne is a semiconductor with large electron mobility
and peculiar conductance behavior. The molar absorptivity has been measured for
long polyynes showing an increase with the chain length. For polyyne of 20 carbon atoms, the experimental value reaches 7.5 ×105 L-1 mol-1 cm [210]. In a word, the
sp-carbon-based nanoscale system seems to have infinite potential and much work is
needed in order to unveil the potential of this “new” member in the vast family of
carbon-based materials.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have summarized the recent developments regarding 0D GQDs
with sp2-hybridized carbon atoms and 2D GDYs with sp- and sp2-hybridization for
energy storage and conversion applications including supercapacitors, LIBs and solar
cells. An overview of the promising properties of 1D carbyne with sp-hybridization is
given. Although a series of functional systems derived from GQDs and GDYs had
been successfully constructed and applied in the energy fields, many challenges still
need to be explored. For GQDs, plenty of synthetic methods have been reported,
which results in huge heterogeneity and the fact that the PL properties of GQDs are
intriguingly determined by numerous parameters, making the tunable luminescence
mechanism waits discovery. Besides, how to improve the quantum yield and
fluorescence intensity are also needs to be solved. A low-cost effective approach is
greatly desirable to produce massive GQDs. It is worth mentioning that the severe
safety hazards for the electrochemical energy storage devices caused by the battery
short-circuit, thermal runaway, and failure with possible explosion or fire are critical
40
and challenge issues for practical applications. Even so, there is no doubt that the
practical promising prospects of GQDs are very bright, and their applications will
definitely alleviate energy problems. The high electron mobility of GQDs could
improve the conductivity and greatly facilitate the charge transport, which is a big
advantage for supercapacitors and LIBs. This feature even possibly enables GQDs as
a suitable hole conductor in DSSCs. The introduction of GQDs as an electrode
material is rather appealing due to the affordable accessibility of ion
adsorption/desorption derived from large surface area and abundant surface sites, as
well as the effective agglomeration suppression and volume expansion alleviation.
With the development of new assembling methods and techniques, multidimensional
systems and the hybrid/composition of GQDs will further benefit the energy-related
devices. For example, in heterojunction solar cells, modified GQDs with an improved
energy alignment could theoretically work as an electron donor as well, showing the
possibility that charge transfer may take place even between two types of GQDs and
therefore forming an interesting junction completely based on GQDs.
The research on GDYs is still at the infant stage although there are numerous
published studies on related topics. What we know is only the tip of the iceberg. So
far, the preparation of high quality single- or few-layer GDYs has been crucial.
Specific characterization techniques are highly required to analyze the GDY
structures such as percentage of C-C triple bonds. GDY shows competitive properties
and exhibits greater potential than many carbon materials for application in energy
sustainability, such as wide interlayer spacing, large specific surface area, unique pore
structure and excellent electrical conductivity. However, more efforts are needed to
further improve the electrode/device performance. In addition, it is worth noticing that
GY is a class of materials and research studies should not be limited to GDY.
Developing new members of the GY family is also attractive.
Even though the existence of carbyne as the ‘third carbon allotrope’ is
controversial, sp-carbon nanostructures can be synthesized in stable forms and are
subsequently investigated now. The strong structure–property relationships allow the
tuning of optical and electronic behavior over a large variety of desired applications.
41
The structure and the functional properties can be designed by controlling the number
of carbon atoms and endgroups, which provides the possibility to adjust the properties
ranging from metallic through semiconducting to insulating for new nanosystems. It
will be rather appealing for carbon science and have great potential in nano/molecular
electronics and optoelectronics fields. However, although the seemingly limitless
potential of sp-carbon-based nanosystems has been suggested in many theoretical
studies, only a small part of the experimental realm has been obtained. Much work is
still needed to unveil the potential of this “new” member in the vast carbon material
family.
Acknowledgement.
Y. Wang and P. Yang contribute equally to this work. The authors would like to
acknowledge the support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China
(Grant No. 51702287), Natural Science Foundation of Zhejiang Province
(LY15B030007), Research Projects of Education Department of Zhejiang Province
(Y201738057) and Natural Science Foundation of Ningbo (2017A610064).
